title: Spring force-derive an equation relating distances

content.question: A vertical spring is attached to the floor, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. An object of mass <math alttext="m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> is placed on top of the spring and slowly lowered, compressing the spring a distance <math alttext="x sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> from its unstretched length, until it reaches equilibrium, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Next, an object of mass <math alttext="m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math> is placed on top of the first object and slowly lowered, compressing the spring an additional distance <math alttext="x sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The system is again in equilibrium in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. Which of the following correctly relates <math alttext="x sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="x sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>?
